title: 108_s1067
content: The "AIDS Corps Act of 2003" may be cited as the AIDS Corps. The President shall establish a pilot program to facilitate the service of health care professionals from the United States in areas severely affected by HIV/AIDS, tuberculosis, and malaria. To participate, individuals must be U.S. citizens or lawfully residing aliens, trained health care professionals meeting educational and licensure requirements. The President shall establish a pilot program for U.S. health care professionals to provide services in areas affected by HIV/AIDS, tuberculosis, and malaria. Participants must provide on-the-job training, health care education, and basic health care services for those infected and affected by the diseases. The President shall ensure wide distribution of information on the program established for U.S. health care professionals to serve in areas affected by HIV/AIDS, tuberculosis, and malaria. Participants will be placed in the poorest areas of affected countries where health care needs are greatest, consulting with relevant officials and community leaders. The President may offer incentives to encourage individuals to participate in the program for U.S. health care professionals to serve in areas affected by HIV/AIDS, tuberculosis, and malaria, including partial payment of loans for educational expenses, deferment of repayments, ensuring retirement benefits, and other incentives as determined appropriate. Participants in the program will be covered under the Federal Tort Claims Act. Participants in the program will be considered U.S. Government employees for specific purposes under federal laws. The President must report on the establishment of the program within 18 months, detailing recruitment processes, candidate selection criteria, and incentives offered. The program participants will be U.S. Government employees. The President must report on the program's establishment within 18 months, including recruitment processes, selection criteria, and incentives. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2004 through 2008.
